Sorry I haven't been active here much recently, folks -- busy with (*sigh*) 
real-world, non-Gladiator stuff :) Anyway, here are a few answers to 
questions and comments, although they may have been answered already.

>Soon I'll have learned LPC and C++...  what are Glad and G:BF written in?
>             -Tevildo, Prince of Cats.

Both are written in C++. Gladiator 3.X is written using the Watcom C++ 
compiler (10.0a); GBF is written using Microsoft Visual C++ (Win32 code).

>Say I just used the editor and used an illegal color. If I delete that
>image, will my scen.exe get restored???

Yep, it should, if I understand the question correctly.

>My own worst opponent in fighting gladiator is a faerie.  For pete's
>sake, those faeries freeze mages and archmages (my favorite
>characters) longer than anything else.  Yep, they freeze a fire
>elemental and clerics for less time with the same hit.  Why?

I believe we made the freeze duration partially dependent on the target's 
constitution -- thus, mages and archmages will tend to stay frozen longer, 
all else being equal.

>That brings me to an interesting question:  Is there anything in the
>game that would keep a team of 1 from being frozen in place
>INDEFINITELY?  I mean a character could be surrounded by faeries and
>continiously fired upon and never have a chance to respond because of
>the damn faeries.

That's one of few things that tends to discourage the "run through the game 
with one super character" method of play :)

>Sounds cool! What exactly CAN the editor do? All I did was make a guy called
>"punkyguy" (and now the scenario editor won't work)...

The simple answer is that Editor was designed to edit the simple graphics 
files (The PIX files) in the game. Initially, we also used it to design the 
levels, doing exactly what people have said: setting to a specific "color" 
to represent a tile, and then drawing a level .. once we had a chance, we 
developed scen.exe to make creating levels easier.

--Tom
